detaileddescription.para: CMake allows building wxWidgets on various platforms with your preferred build system.
Most linux distributions contain CMake as a package on Windows and macOS you can download an installer at the CMake Page.

listitem.para: Specify the wxWidgets root as your source folder
Specify a path where the build files should be created. It's recommended to use a path outside the wxWidgets root folder.
Press the Configure button and you will be asked which IDE or build system you wish to use
Optionally: Customize any of the options
Open the wxWidgets project with your preferred IDE

sect1.title: Using the CMake Command Line

listitem.para: Create a folder where the build/project files should be created
After that you can run cmake --build . to start the build process or directly use your chosen build system.

sect1.para: Run cmake --help to see a list of available generators on your platform. These can than be specified using the -G command line option. On Windows it is recommended to use Visual Studio and on macOS Xcode is recommended. Various build options can be specified using -D see available options.

sect2.title: Command Line Examples
sect2.para: Building with tests using Ninja: cmake-G"Ninja"~/Downloads/wxWidgets_3.1-DwxBUILD_TESTS=ALL cmake--build.
Installing static libraries to some path: cmake~/Downloads/wxWidgets_3.1\ -DCMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX=~/wx_install\ -DwxBUILD_SHARED=OFF cmake--build.--targetinstall

sect1.title: Build options
sect1.para: The following list of build options can either be configured in the CMake UI or specified via the -D command line option when running the cmake command.
A complete list of options and advanced options can be found when using the CMake GUI.

sect1.title: Recommendations
sect1.para:
While CMake in wxWidgets aims to support most generators available in CMake the following generators are recommended:
Windows: Visual Studio (any supported version)
macOS: Xcode
Linux: Ninja or Makefiles
CMake 3.10 or newer is recommended. The minimum version required is 2.8.12.

sect1.title: Using CMake with your applications
sect1.para:
If you are using CMake with your own application there are various ways to use wxWidgets:
Using an installed, binary or compiled version of wxWidgets using find_package()
wxWidgets as a sub directory.
CMake's ExternalProject module.

sect2.title: Using find_package
sect2.para: You can use find_package(wxWidgets) to use a compiled version of wxWidgets. Have a look at the CMake Documentation for detailed instructions.

Your CMakeLists.txt would look like this: ...
find_package(wxWidgetsREQUIREDCOMPONENTSnetcorebase) include(${wxWidgets_USE_FILE}) add_executable(myappmyapp.cpp) target_link_libraries(myapp${wxWidgets_LIBRARIES})

sect2.title: Using a sub directory
sect2.para: You can use wxWidgets as a subdirectory in your application's build tree e.g. as a git submodule. This way the wxWidgets libraries will be part of your applications build process.
Your CMakeLists.txt would look like this: ... add_subdirectory(libs/wxWidgets) add_executable(myappmyapp.cpp) target_link_libraries(myappwx::netwx::corewx::base)
